pull.title: Text and language editing of release-notes.md
pull.body: Rewrapped text (which was mangled a bit in email); made small language changes for readability, punctuation, and such. Did _not_ touch anything after the subhead "0.9.0rc2 Release notes". This is the first contribution by me (tgeller); see https://sourceforge.net/p/bitcoin/mailman/message/32046281/ to understand why I did it as I did, and please correct me if I've done anything wrong. Thanks!

events.message:
Text and language editing of release-notes.md

Rewrapped text (which was mangled a bit in email); made small language changes for readability, punctuation, and such. Did *not* touch anything after the subhead "0.9.0rc2 Release notes". This is the first contribution by me (tgeller); see https://sourceforge.net/p/bitcoin/mailman/message/32046281/ to understand why I did it as I did, and please correct me if I've done anything wrong. Thanks!

events.body:
Automatic sanity-testing: FAILED MERGE, see http://jenkins.bluematt.me/pull-tester/0aefd548e9ec9da400c16fea09b3a6ad85fd0578 for test log.

This pull does not merge cleanly onto current master
This test script verifies pulls every time they are updated. It, however, dies sometimes and fails to test properly.  If you are waiting on a test, please check timestamps to verify that the test.log is moving at http://jenkins.bluematt.me/pull-tester/current/
Contact BlueMatt on freenode if something looks broken.
This conflicts with another change made to the same file. Please rebase your commit.
What does that mean? How do I do that?
Ah. It means someone else edited the file whilst you were editing it, and you changed the same parts of the file. Git (the tool) has a way to fix this but I'm not sure github the web UI does.

You can fix it locally, by cloning your fork of the repo and using the rebase command.

```
git clone https://github.com/tgeller/bitcoin
cd bitcoin
git checkout patch-1
git rebase
git push --force
```
ACK apart from my above nit; check that the rendered document still looks ok
Seems this is a request to merge in 0.9, rather than in master.
@sipa Which makes sense. Master is the next major release. Updates to the release notes for 0.9 should go in the 0.9 branch.

@laanwj I was confused by seeing the rc2 release note changes as part of this PR. Why aren't those in 0.9.0 or master yet?

Is master supposed to become 0.9.1?

@sipa Gavin made the 0.9.0rc2 release notes based on the 0.9.0rc1 ones but didn't update them in git.

As I understand it, master will become 0.10.0 (or 1.0.0). If there is a 0.9.1 it makes sense to base it on the 0.9.0 branch. This is also what we did for 0.8.x (at least the latter ones, we only forked the 0.8 branch from master at 0.8.2).
I believe I combined the changes here with those that Gavin made in his notes. See the latest pull request at https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/3797 .

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -41,60 +55,95 @@ have renamed the reference client to Bitcoin Core.
 Autotools build system
 -----------------------
 
-For 0.9.0 we switched to an autotools-based build system instead of individual
-(q)makefiles.
+For 0.9.0 we switched to an autotools-based build system instead of
+individual (q)makefiles.
 
-Using the standard ./autogen.sh; ./configure; make to build Bitcoin-Qt and
-bitcoind makes it easier for experienced open source developers to contribute
-to the project.
+Using the standard "./autogen.sh; ./configure; make" to build Bitcoin-Qt
+and bitcoind makes it easier for experienced open source developers to
+contribute to the project.
 
-Be sure to check doc/build-*.md for your platform before building from source.
+Be sure to check doc/build-*.md for your platform before building from
+source.
 
 Bitcoin-cli
 -------------
 
-Another change in the 0.9 release is moving away from the bitcoind executable
-functioning both as a server and as a RPC client. The RPC client functionality
-(tell the running bitcoin daemon to do THIS) was split into a separate
-executable, 'bitcoin-cli'. The RPC client code will eventually be removed from
-bitcoind, but will be kept for backwards compatibility for a release or two.
+Another change in the 0.9.0 release is that the bitcoind executable
+no longer functions as both a server and as a RPC client. The RPC
+client functionality ("tell the running bitcoin daemon to do THIS") was
+split into a separate executable, "bitcoin-cli". The RPC client code
+will eventually be removed from bitcoind, but will be kept for backwards
+compatibility for a release or two.
 
 `walletpassphrase` RPC
 -----------------------
 
-The behavior of the `walletpassphrase` RPC when the wallet is already unlocked
-has changed between 0.8 and 0.9.
+The behavior of the `walletpassphrase` RPC when the wallet is already
+unlocked has changed between 0.8 and 0.9.
+
+The 0.8 behavior of `walletpassphrase` is to fail when the wallet is
+already unlocked:
+
+walletpassphrase 1000
comments.body:
Please keep the indentation at 4 for "code samples"

Look at the rendered document: https://github.com/tgeller/bitcoin/blob/patch-1/doc/release-notes.md
Versus the old one: https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/0.9.0/doc/release-notes.md
